subtitle.text: The Three Wishes
There once was a lumberjack named Mr. Thomas.
One day, he went to an old forest and began chopping down a tree.
He sang, "Chopping down the tree, as easy as can be.
Chopping down the tree, and counting one, two, three."
Just then, a little fairy flew out of the tree.
"Stop!" she cried.
"That's my house."
"My lady," said Mr.
Thomas, bowing, "I'm sorry." He set his ax down.
The fairy was pleased.
"Kind man, I'll give your family three wishes."
"Three wishes?" asked Mr. Thomas.
"Yes," she said.
"Just say the magic words, 'I wish.'"
Then fairy dust sparkled through the air, and the fairy disappeared.
Mr. Thomas saw the magic, but he still couldn't believe it.
"Hmph," he said, and walked away.
That evening, when Mr. Thomas got home, he was hungry.
"I wish I had some sausage," he said.
Fairy dust sparkled, and sausage filled the table.
"The wishes are real!" he cried.
Just then, his family came home.
"What's that smell?" asked his son Johnny.
"Sausage!" said his son Jack.
"I'm hungry," said his daughter Jane.
"Where's it from?" asked Mrs. Thomas.
Mr. Thomas told them about the fairy.
"We have two wishes left. What do you want?" he asked.
"I want a toy," said Johnny.
"I want a present," said Jack.
"I want a doll," said Jane.
But Mrs. Thomas didn't believe him.
She thought he was lying.
"Hmph," she said.
"I wish your nose was a sausagel"
Fairy dust sparkled, and Mr. Thomas's nose turned into a sausage.
"Ahh!" he yelled.
"Help me, Johnny," said Mr. Thomas.
So Johnny pulled on the sausage nose, but it just got longer.
"Oh, no," said the boy.
Then Jack joined Johnny, and they both pulled on the sausage nose.
"It's still getting longer!" said Jack.
Then Jane joined them, and they all pulled on the sausage nose.
"Daddy's sausage nose is growing!" Jane yelled.
Finally, Mrs. Thomas joined them, and they all pulled on the sausage nose.
"I wish I had my nose backl" yelled Mr. Thomas.
Fairy dust sparkled, and the sausage nose disappeared.
Mr. Thomas's family flew backward through the air.
Johnny yelled, "Daddy got his nose back!"
"Thank goodness," said Mr. Thomas.
"No more wishesl"
"No toys," said Johnny.
"No presents," said Jack.
"No dolls," said Jane.
"But LOTS of sausage," said Mrs. Thomas, and they all laughed and had sausage for dinner.
